Operational optimization of heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems is crucial to achieving economic and environmental benefits. However, owing to the dynamic supply capability (DSC) and distributed demand response (DDR), large-scale HVAC systems that integrate multiple distributed sources with demanders are increasingly being developed to resemble distributed energy systems (DESs); thus, the traditional centralized strategies are now facing unprecedented challenges. With the application of wireless communication and sensor network technology, distributed schemes that allow the modular integration of an arbitrary number of suppliers and demanders have attached widespread interest of researchers. However, existing distributed optimization schemes that focus on either multi-zone temperature or equipment group efficiency are unilateral and non-interfering. In this work, we developed a data-oriented distributed overall optimization strategy for large-scale HVAC systems with DSC and DDR. We first suggested an agent-based distributed overall optimization framework that defines the roles of participants in distributed optimization and clarifies their duties, mechanisms, and relationships with each other, thus bridging the supply-side and demand-side decisions. Then, we exploited state-of-the-art data-driven models and designed a bi-level optimization algorithm, where the heuristic algorithm works as the lower-level scheme and the Nash-optimization algorithm acts as the upper-level scheme, to implement the distributed overall optimization. Last, a hardware-in-the-loop simulation was performed, and time-series data were collected to validate our proposed optimization strategy. Compared with centralized strategies, it can obtain better operational performance by paying a lower computational cost. This work provides a reference for optimizing increasingly complex HVAC systems. error LF Loss function HRC Hydrodynamic resistance characteristics RF Reset frequency CPN Computing process node LAN Local area network 1 Introduction The global carbon dioxide emissions reached 36440.8 million tons in 2020, showing an increasing of 21.1 million tons over the previous year [1]. According to statistics, building carbon dioxide emissions account for approximately 36% of the total emissions [2], among which a large portion could be attributed to thermal comfort overhead [3]. Heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems are one of the most relevant aspects in terms of energy conservation and thermal comfort in the building sector, which are crucial for achieving economic and environmental benefits [4]. Developing operational optimization techniques for HVAC systems will greatly contribute to fulfilling the future low-carbon strategic goal. Owing to the complexity of the thermodynamic behaviors of systems and the demand randomness caused by multiple occupants and weather forecasts, the optimization of HVAC systems is not a trivial task [3]. Furthermore, with the increasing penetration of distributed renewable energy (DRE) sources, owing to their considerable unpredictability and variability [5], the enhancement of operational flexibility is essential to achieve a real-time supply-demand balance of HVAC systems. Demand-side management (DSM) strategies that are born in electricity field and widely used for electricity management [6,7], such as distributed demand response (DDR) and energy efficiency measure (EEM) [5], have significant potential for unlocking energy flexibility [8,9]. Compared with supply-side management (SSM), DSM is more cost-effective for investor [5,7], where actions are taken to modify load demand, thus addressing supply shortages, because of which DSM has gradually aroused widespread attention in distributed energy systems (DESs) [9]. Simultaneously, owing to the complex complementary couplings between various energy resources [10] and the DDR from end-users or building energy systems (BESs) [10], the adjustable capability of DESs exhibits dynamic characteristics [10]. In other words, a large-scale HVAC system that integrates multiple distributed sources with demanders is shaped like a DES with a dynamic supply capability (DSC) and DDR. In particular, in district heating and cooling (DHC) systems, the secondary networks are closely connected with occupants or BESs, with their potential to integrate local sustainable resources and industry or municipal surplus energy, and because of the slighter impact on the environment and climate, they are attracting increased interest from local authorities and developers [12]. However, the implementation of DSM requires careful planning and appropriate decision making to obtain a relative balance of interests between supply and demand [6]. Therefore, the optimization of large-scale HVAC systems has evolved into a collaborative task, which poses unprecedented challenges to the traditional centralized strategies where a leadership node must pick up global complete information [13]. For instance, because of the communication delay introduced in issuing dispatch orders, the local decision making cannot quickly perceive topological perturbations, thus failing to achieve rapid reference tracking [13]. In addition, a powerful computation center used to cope with an intractable computation burden is indispensable for deployment in system management [13], which is inextensible and costly. With the application of wireless communication and sensor network technology, the distributed strategies that decompose the original problem into multiple parallel subproblems with coupling have attracted widespread interest in HVAC system research [13,14]. In a distributed architecture, a feasible solution can be updated by participants interacting with local incomplete information; then, the global objective cost can be minimized [13,15], which greatly lightens the computational burden. What's more, the extensibility of distributed architecture allows the modular integration of an arbitrary number of suppliers and demanders [16] and avoids software updates when new demanders and suppliers access the system [13]. Therefore, the development of distributed strategies is promising with increasingly complex HVAC systems. In recent years, several researchers have devoted themselves to developing distributed strategies for HVAC system optimization. Dai et al. introduced a novel distributed method for the optimum allocation of equipment groups, such as the pump and chiller groups, in response to a given demand under actual constraints [17]. Compared with the traditional centralized control method, this distributed control method is much more flexible and scalable. Yu et al. proposed a distributed control structure for parallel pumps, in which the integrated controller was replaced by several independent distributed controllers cooperating to handle the global task [14]. An artificial fish swarm algorithm (AFSA) was included in the proposed structure to optimize the pumps working in the parallel mode. Wang et al. performed a decentralized estimation of the distribution algorithm under a local interaction game framework to optimize pumps working in the parallel mode [18]. Sun et al. presented an equilibrium optimization algorithm for optimizing the chiller load dispatch of a HVAC system for energy conversation [19]. Wang et al. proposed an efficient distributed model predictive control (MPC) scheme based on Nash optimality for a single-duct variable air volume (VAV) air-conditioning system [20]. Li et al. presented a distributed MPC approach for room temperature in multi-zone buildings with hydraulic coupling [15]. Mtibaa et al. presented a novel online data-driven control framework called model predictive control via genetic algorithm (MPC-GA), which allows the optimal operation of a HVAC system [21]. The above-mentioned research demonstrates that distributed strategies perform excellently in optimizing multi-zone temperature acting as multiple demands and equipment group efficiency serving as multiple supplies. However, their operations are unilateral and non-interfering, and focus on either the supply-side allocation [14,17–19] or demand-side coupling [15,20,21] in HVAC systems. For instance, allocation optimization of equipment groups in an energy station is conducted under the assumption of picking up a real-time load response. In fact, the load of buildings is acquired uneasily, and cannot reflect the real demands owing to thermal inertia and lag [22]. On the other side, the implementation of the optimal control strategy for room temperature in a multi-zone building lacks full consideration of the supply-side operating efficiency and limitations. In 2002, Wemstedt and Davidsson suggested a multi-agent system architecture for district heating (DH) systems, where three types of agent including consumer agent, redistribution agent and producer agent, and two working mechanisms, competition and cooperation, were initially defined [23]. They argued that agents are appropriate for applications that are modular, decentralized, changeable, ill-structured, and complex, which promotes the implementation of distributed strategies in DESs [23]. In 2007, Wemstedt and Davidsson clarified the above architecture for DSM in DH systems, where three layers composing of the strategic layer, heuristic layer and operational layer, were presented [24]. They further stated that an agent-based approach is more robust, efficient, flexible, open, scalable and economical than the centralized counterpart. In 2018, Felix et al. exploited an analogous architecture to optimize and control low-temperature networks [16]. In 2020, Cai et al. developed a communication structure with dual agents including the load agent and network agent, for DDR in DH systems, and the information flow was transferred via the MQTT broker [25]. In 2021, Lorenzo et al. defined an end-user agent and central plant agent to address the peak-shaving problem in DH systems [26]. In the same year, Li et al. formulated two coordination frameworks, centralized and decentralized frameworks, involving multiple DESs with flexible sources [27]. The results showed that the decentralized framework can mitigate privacy issues and decrease the internal energy flow. The above research indicates that agent-based control architecture is applicable for dealing with DDR in DESs. However, these pyramid-shaped frameworks [16,23,24], where the top agent represents the source with production capacity, bottom agents denote occupants with thermal demands, and middle agents work as brokers for information transmission, do not consider DSC from multi-energy complementary couplings in the optimization of DESs. Besides, brokers between the producer and consumer agents only act as links through which information flows and have no definite role [16,25]. Therefore, for large-scale HVAC systems with DSC and DDR, a universal framework applicable to distributed overall optimization needs to be urgently established to bridge the supply-side and demand-side decisions. Our first task is to design an agent-based framework by extracting nature to define the roles of participants in the distributed overall optimization, and their duties and mechanisms. In such a framework, optimization models and algorithms are vital for optimum strategy implementation. Common models for optimizing HVAC systems mainly include physics-based and data-driven models [28]. Cai et al. summarized mathematical descriptions for the DH network and building heating demand and then exploited them to optimize the distributed agent-based heating demand for DH systems [25]. Li et al. established mathematical models for energy production, conversion, and storage to analyze the techno-economic and environmental performance of DESs [27]. However, as is well known, the HVAC system is a nonlinear system with time delays, multiple variables, and strong coupling, and building physics-based models based on laws of mass, momentum, and energy conservation is laborious [28,29]. With advances in monitoring systems, computing, and communication devices, data-driven models that reduce the cost and time consumption have been favored [30]. For instance, a multiple linear perceptron (MLP) modeling a chiller, pump, fan, and reheating device for energy minimization was presented in Ref. [31]. The optimization results demonstrated that the total energy consumed by the HVAC system was reduced by over 7%. In Ref. [32], an artificial neural network (ANN) model-based predictive control method was developed, and the results showed that a comfortable temperature can be maintained with reduced energy consumption. In Ref. [33], Garnier et al. developed low-order ANN-based models as the controller's internal models within the predictive control of multi-zone HVAC systems in non-residential buildings, and all HVAC subsystems were operated using the proposed strategy with results showing that energy consumption was minimized and thermal comfort requirements were met. In Ref. [34], Afram et al. trained an appropriate ANN architecture to design a supervisory MPC for residential HVAC systems, and the results showed that the operating costs can be saved by 6%–73% depending on the season. Furthermore, recently, gated recurrent neural networks (RNNs), such as long short-term memory (LSTM) networks and gated recurrent unit (GRU) networks, as sophisticated tools have been extensively applied for time-series prediction in HVAC systems [35]. Hence, in this study, a GRU with relatively few learning parameters was selected as a predictive control model to identify real-time demands for occupants. For equipment groups, their models can be described by polynomials, where the patterns have been empirically solidified [14,17,18], and only parameters need to be estimated using common algorithms like regression [36]. The data-driven modelling technique is a natural way to cope with HVAC systems, but as mentioned above, the model of each module was mostly used separately in previous research [14–21]. In the overall optimization of HVAC systems, it is not clear where tunable variables, such as supplied flow and temperature, identified by state-of-the-art strategies like MPC, are used and how to use them. Thus, it is important for a large-scale HVAC system to formulate an overall optimization strategy to activate each participant. One the other hand, owing to nonlinear expressions, heuristic algorithms such as the genetic algorithm (GA) [33,37], particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm [15,31,34], and AFSA [14] are usually used to search for the optimal solution in ANN-MPC and load allocation tasks. However, single heuristic algorithms are prone to fall into the local optimum in later evolution [34], especially for high-dimensional spaces in the overall HVAC system [15]. Hence, to guarantee optimum solutions and adapt to the distributed optimization framework, we designed a bi-level optimization algorithm in which the heuristic algorithm works as the lower-level scheme and the Nash-optimization algorithm serves as the upper-level scheme, to decompose the original optimization problem into multiple parallel handy subproblems with coupling. Therefore, in this study, we exploit state-of-the-art data-driven models and a bi-level optimization algorithm to develop a data-oriented distributed optimization strategy for a large-scale HVAC system by adapting to the agent-based distributed overall optimization framework. Finally, for the overall optimization of a large-scale HVAC system with multiple suppliers and demanders, balancing between supply and demand is key to bridging their gap, thus saving energy and ensuring thermal comfort, which involves pipelines and valves. Conventional hydraulic balance methods for HVAC networks have been developed based on graph theory [11,15,38,39], among which it is essential to identify hydraulic resistances by model calibration [11,38,39] or real-time calculation [14,18,40]. For the former, the hydraulic resistances of pipelines, valves, and power equipment are estimated in advance using the Darcy equation valve characteristic curve, and polynomial fitting [11,39]. These models are then calibrated using the measured data from on-site meters and the implementation of an optimization program [38]. Once the accuracy of these theoretical models falls within an acceptable range, a system hydraulic optimization procedure based on graph theory can be launched. This method has been validated in many studies [11,38,39], but precise modeling is difficult and time-consuming, particularly for complex HVAC systems. For the latter, the calculation based on real-time monitoring data seems very simple; however, the demand-side valve openings are not considered in the optimization. In pipe networks, when the flow demands change, hydraulic resistance provides negative feedback. This simple calculation may exacerbate the imbalance between supply and demand or cause more severe energy consumption. In fact, the demand-side valves can not only serve as coordinators between supply and demand, but also mirror the imbalance between them [41]. In Chapter 41 of the 2007 ASHRAE Handbook HVAC Applications, a strategy in which the optimal supplied pressure head (SPH) in the HAVC system is devoted to maintaining one of the demand-side valves to almost be fully open at all times was first introduced [41], which attracted the attention of researchers. In 2009, Wang et al. developed a modified strategy in which a supply air temperature control loop was added to reset the differential pressure (DP) set-point for variable-speed pumps in a complex air-conditioning system [42]. Compared with the original strategy with fixed steps [43], the improved strategy can reduce the energy consumption by approximately 12.69%–32.43%. Subsequently, Zhao et al. innovatively defined the most unfavorable thermodynamic loop as the branch in which the valve is almost fully opened but the demand cannot be satisfied [44], which distinguishes it from the most unfavorable hydraulic loop under design operational conditions. Then, a linear rule [44,45] and a fuzzy rule [46] for DP set-point reset based on the maximum valve position were proposed successively and applied in a chilled water system and VAV system, respectively, and the results showed that energy-saving rates can reach up to 58% and 33%, respectively, compared with the constant-volume operation strategy. Furthermore, in 2019, Li et al. improved the original fuzzy rule using a modified Mamdani model for static pressure reset in a VAV system which exhibited better control performance and energy-saving potential [47]. From the above research, we can see that the optimal SPH set-point based on the maximum valve position in the HVAC system is enough and just enough for the most heavily loaded occupant, which successfully ensures the overall thermal comfort with the minimum energy consumption. Thus, the SPH set-point reset strategy based on the demand-side valve positions can avoid the intricate calculations to balance supply and demand in the HVAC system. The only flaw in the solution is that the existing strategies take the maximum valve position as the only evaluation index without fully considering the stability and security of a system, especially for a large-scale HVAC system. Therefore, in this study, we further improve SPH set-point reset strategies as a more credible method to balance between supply and demand. Therefore, the contributions of this study mainly lie threefold: a) For increasingly complex HVAC systems with multiple suppliers and demanders, we presented an agent-based distributed overall optimization framework to bridge the supply-side and demand-side decisions. b) We developed a data-oriented distributed optimization strategy for a large-scale HVAC system, adapting it to state-of-the-art data-driven models and an agent-based distributed overall optimization framework. c) We improved the existing SPH set-point reset strategies based on demand-side valve positions by promoting stability and security to balance supply and demand for a large-scale HVAC system. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents an agent-based distributed overall optimization framework for the large-scale HVAC system; Section 3 introduces data-oriented optimization models for the supplier and demander, and the improved SPH set-point reset strategies serving to balance supplies and demands; Section 4 shows a bi-level optimization algorithm to solve the overall HVAC system optimization; Section 5 provides our validation schemes; Results and discussion are detailed in Section 6; Conclusions are presented in Section 7. 2 Agent-based distributed overall optimization framework For HVAC systems, whatever they are air-conditioning systems or heating systems, the optimization operations are analogous. Hence, it is necessary to formulate a universal overall optimization framework for a complex HVAC system with DSC and DDR. Besides, the distributed architecture using neighbor communication instead of the scheduling center and radial communication favors the overall optimization with distributed strategies and the sustainable development owing to its simpler configuration, higher reliability, and better extendibility. Therefore, in this section, we summarize the optimization essence to design an agent-based framework, thus expounding on how to realize the distributed overall optimization of HVAC systems. Fig. 1 presents an agent-based distributed overall optimization framework for a typical district heating (DH) system, where occupants and heating substations are dispersed across a vast terrain. As shown in Fig. 1, participants in the overall HVAC system optimization are divided into three types of roles: producer, consumer, and coordinator agents. Producer agents refer to energy suppliers, such as heating and cooling substations in secondary networks or heating and cooling sources in primary networks. Consumer agents refer to thermal demanders such as building energy systems (BESs) or occupants. Coordinator agents work on balancing supplies and demands and mirroring the imbalance between them, which generally are served by regulators. Each agent performs its duties and collaborates with others. Consumer agents convey real-time thermal demands to their coordinators by perceiving future weather parameters and assessing the status quo. Coordinator agents receive request signals and confer them to neighbors via a network to share prospective behaviors and then give reasonable adjustment schemes. Producer agents respond to thermal demands and adjustment schemes and deduce an optimal production schedule by consulting with others. Thus, consumer agents and coordinator agents update the thermal demands and adjustment schemes under the presumptive production schedule. The entire process is performed in the coupling decisions. The overall optimization task is completed through collaboration between agents, but each decision is independently made by the corresponding agent. The specific working mechanisms of the different agents are as follows: a) Consumer agents provide real-time thermal demands by identifying tunable variables such as supplied flow using the MPC method. b) Coordinator agents perceive the surrounding hydraulic conditions and make self-adapting adjustments such as valve positions to meet demands, and then confer with each other to provide a reasonable SPH set-point for large-scale HVAC systems. c) Producer agents evaluate the energy consumption and launch an optimal production schedule such as equipment on-off and frequency, according to demands and the reset scheme for the SPH set-point in the HVAC system. The above procedures form an overall optimization framework for a large-scale HVAC system under the distributed architecture, where, for each participant, its role, duty, mechanisms, and relationship with each other are clarified. In this agent-based distributed overall optimization framework, once an excellent optimization strategy is implemented, the energy conservation goals of HVAC systems can be realized on the premise of satisfying the thermal demands of the occupants. 3 Data-oriented optimization models For all agents, we should not only define and validate their working mechanisms, but also clarify the optimization relationships between agents. 3.1 GRU model-based predictive control For consumer agents, a GRU-based indoor temperature predictive control was developed to predict the real-time demand for occupants under the available weather forecast. This subsection focuses on the GRU-based prediction model for indoor temperature and the cost function of MPC. 3.1.1 GRU-based prediction model The GRU-based prediction model established a nonlinear relationship between the indoor temperature and tunable variables in the HVAC system. Herein, variable flow ( G w t ) regulation is considered. The GRU network, as a simplified LSTM, integrates the former forget and input gates as an update gate to reduce the learning parameters without affecting the performance [35]. The cellular architecture of the GRU, which is composed of a reset gate and an update gate, is shown in Fig. 2 . The forward calculation formula for the GRU can be expressed as follows: (1) Γ r t = σ ( W r h t − 1 + U r x t ) (2) Γ u t = σ ( W u h t − 1 + U u x t ) (3) h ˜ t = tan h [ W h ( Γ r t ⊙ h t − 1 ) + U h x t ] (4) h t = ( 1 − Γ u t ) ⊙ h t − 1 + Γ u t ⊙ h ˜ t (5) y t = g ( W p h t ) (6) e r r t = T t − y t wherein, Γ r t and Γ u t represent the output of the reset gate and update gate, respectively; h ˜ t and h t denote the candidate hidden state and hidden state, respectively; x t , y t , T t and e r r t represent the input, output, goal and error of the cell in turn; W r , W u , W h , U r , U u , U h and W p indicate the weight matrices corresponding to the hidden state and cellular input in the reset gate, update gate and candidate hidden state, and the weight matrix in cellular output; σ is the sigmoid activation function; g can be selected as a linear activation function; ⊙ represents Hadamard product implemented on matrices; t is the current sampling time. Parameter learning with backpropagation through time (BPTT) in GRU can be described by the following formulas, where the mean square error loss function is adopted and weight matrices are updated by the Levenberg-Marquardt (LM) algorithm [48]. The calculated weight gradients in Eq. (9) can be seen in Appendix A. To evaluate the performance of the GRU model for indoor temperature prediction, the root-mean-square error (RMSE), mean absolute percentage error (MAPE), and correlation index ( R 2 ) were selected as three evaluation metrics [49]. The cost function is based on the desired behavior of the system and serves to stabilize the system. It also describes the performance target in HVAC systems, such as the minimization of energy consumption and the maximization of thermal comfort. Herein, the cost function is defined as the weighted sum of the tracking error and control effort, i.e. the predicted output is hypothesized to be closer to the reference input, and consideration given to the change of input control sequence ( Δ G w t ) is as small as possible [51,52]. The optimization for the cost function in MPC is detailed in Section 4. 3.2 Equipment groups model In this study, using the secondary network of DH system as a reference, producer agents only involve multiple parallel pumps in the heating substations. Their models can be described with polynomials at the rated speed and law of similitude. The pump head and flow of a single variable-speed pump running at a non-rated rotation speed can be scaled from those of the pump running at the rated rotation speed [14,18,38]. The above models were considered within the agent-based distributed overall optimization framework to reflect the DSC for HVAC systems with DRE. 3.3 SPH set-point reset strategy Informed of demands from the consumer agents, coordinator agents make self-adapting adjustments and then confer with each other to give a reasonable SPH set-point. For regulation valves serving as coordinator agents, valve positions can be modulated adaptively based on their own hydrodynamic resistance characteristics (HRC) describing the relationship between flow and pressure difference under full stroke [48]. For the SPH set-point reset strategy, we analyze and compare the existing linear rule and fuzzy rule, and then develop a self-adjusting universe fuzzy rule and a hybrid rule consisting of linear and fuzzy rules for SPH set-point reset based on previous research. 3.3.1 Fuzzy rule Initially, the fuzzy rule for the SPH set-point reset was developed in 2015 to optimally set the supply air static pressure in a VAV system [46]. This strategy can be summarized as follows: (23) S P H t = { S P H t − 1 + Δ S P H t , θ max t ∈ [ θ min , θ s e t m i n ] S P H t − 1 , θ max t ∈ [ θ s e t m i n , θ s e t m a x ] S P H t − 1 + Δ S P H t , θ max t ∈ [ θ s e t m a x , 100 % ] (24) Δ S P H t = M ( e θ t , e c θ t ) wherein, the difference between the maximum damper position feedback value and the center value of the optimal damper position domain is defined as e θ t ; the difference between the current e θ t and previous e θ t − 1 is defined as e c θ t ; θ min denotes the lowest limit of the damper position; θ s e t m i n and θ s e t m a x represent the optimal damper position domain which is given in Ref. [44]; S P H t and Δ S P H t represent the SPH set-point and its change; M ( ∙ ) denotes the Mamdani fuzzy rule implemented on variables. The optimal static pressure set-point can be obtained based on this strategy. However, it is difficult to determine an appropriate universe in a fuzzy model. A smaller universe domain could cause slow adjustment under large deviation and deviation variations, whereas a larger one is likely to produce a steady-state error [53–55]. 3.3.2 Linear rule The linear rule for the SPH set-point reset was originally proposed by Zhao et al. in Refs. [44,45], and the most unfavorable thermodynamic loop was also defined [44]. This strategy can be explained using the following formulas: (25) S P H t = { S P H t − 1 + ( θ max − θ s e t m i n ) S P H t − 1 − S P H min θ s e t m i n − θ min , θ max t ∈ [ θ min , θ s e t m i n ] S P H t − 1 , θ max t ∈ [ θ s e t m i n , θ s e t m a x ] S P H t − 1 + ( θ max − θ s e t m a x ) S P H max − S P H t − 1 100 % − θ s e t m a x , θ max t ∈ [ θ s e t m a x , 100 % ] wherein, S P H min and S P H max represent the bound of the SPH set-point. In the linear rule, it is equivalent to only concerning e θ t , without e c θ t . The change of the SPH set-point varies with different deviation scales, thereby avoiding the shortcomings of the fuzzy rule. Compared with the calculated pressure drop based on the hydraulic resistance at the previous time step, the SPH set-point obtained using this strategy is more reasonable (Fig. 3 ). However, it can be observed that once the deviation occurs, the SPH set-point significantly varies, which increases the reset frequency compared with the former. In particular, for a large-scale HVAC system, a stable hydraulic condition is also essential. Besides, in this rule, the SPH set-point is strictly limited within its bound, without buffering the leeway. In an agent-based distributed overall optimization framework for a large-scale HVAC system, we designed a bi-level optimization algorithm with a distributed idea, where the original complex task is decomposed into a series of simple subtasks to reduce the computational complexity. 4.1 Upper-level scheme The upper-level scheme is implemented using the Nash-optimization algorithm. The Nash-optimization algorithm as a distributed scheme has been extensively applied in multi-objective optimization [56,57]. Owing to the information sharing and cooperation between agents, this method can efficiently improve the control performance and guarantee Nash equilibrium or global optimality [57,58]. It is assumed that q consumer agents and the corresponding coordinator agents, as well as m producer agents, participate in the thermodynamic behaviors of large-scale HVAC systems. At time step t , the optimization problem can be described as follows: (35) Min f i t t = ∑ i = 1 m γ i H i t G i t / η i t + ‖ W ( ∑ i = 1 m G i t − ∑ j = 1 q G j t ) ‖ 2 (36) s . t . { γ i = 1 , ω i min ≤ ω i t ≤ 1 γ i = 0 , 0 ≤ ω i t < ω i min H i t = S P H t / p , A l w a y s wherein, f i t t represents the real-time overall performance index for the HVAC system; γ denotes the on-off factor of the equipment; p denotes the number of equipment groups equal to the number of substations; W is the weight balance between supply and demand. Such an overall optimization task involving multiple agents can be solved using the Nash-optimization algorithm. For each agent, the local performance index can be derived from Eq. (36). (37) Min f i t k t = { f i t j t ( G j t ) , 1 ≤ j ≤ q , a g e n t ∈ C o n s u m e r a g e n t s f i t j t ( θ j t ) , 1 ≤ j ≤ q , a g e n t ∈ C o o r d i n a t o r a g e n t s f i t i t ( ω i t ) , 1 ≤ i ≤ m , a g e n t ∈ P r o d u c e r a g e n t s wherein, f i t k t represents the real-time local performance index of the k-th agent. It can be seen that the local performance index of each agent is related to all variables coupled with each other. For the k-th agent, the Nash optimal solution satisfies the following relation [57,58]. (38) f i t k * ( x 1 N ⋯ x k N ⋯ x m + 2 q N ) ≤ f i t k ( x 1 N ⋯ x k − 1 N , x k t , x k + 1 N ⋯ x m + 2 q N ) wherein, x k N represents the Nash optimal solution of the k-th agent. Each agent cannot change its control decision x k N after the Nash equilibrium is reached; otherwise, the local performance index f i t k * degrades. If the Nash optimal solutions of other agents are acquired, the local performance index of each agent will only be related to its own control decision [57,58]. (39) f i t k t = min x k t f i t k t | x d N ( d = 1,2 , ⋯ , m + 2 q | d ≠ k ) To obtain the Nash optimal solution of the k-th agent, other agents’ Nash optimal solutions need to be known in advance, so that the whole system can arrive at the Nash equilibrium in the coupling decision process. 4.2 Lower-level scheme Presuming the Nash optimal solutions of other agents, the local performance index of the k-th agent only concerns its own control decision. Owing to nonlinearity, we select PSO, a common heuristic algorithm that serves as the lower-level scheme herein. As an evolutionary algorithm, the optimal value is explored through the cooperation between individuals in the PSO algorithm. Owing to its simpler structure and extensive scalability, it has been widely used in model parameter optimization, the principle of which can be easily obtained [15,31,59]. 4.3 Algorithm operation steps For overall HVAC system optimization, the operation steps of the bi-level optimization algorithm are as follows: Image 1 The optimization procedures of a large-scale HVAC system in the agent-based distributed overall optimization framework are shown in Fig. 5 . The future weather parameters and the desired thermal comfort of occupants are perceived. Subsequently, a bi-level optimization algorithm is launched. The upper-level scheme splits this task. Then, consumer agents submit demands; coordinator agents adjust adaptively and issue SPH set-point; and the producer agents rearrange the production schedule. All agents communicate and collaborate with each other to promote overall optimization. 5 Validation schemes 5.1 Hardware-in-the-loop simulation platform To validate the data-oriented distributed optimization strategy, we carried out a hardware-in-the-loop simulation for a simplified DH system, where two heating substations configured with three pumps, serve four public buildings with different thermal comfort demands, and the heating sources supply the heat medium with variable quality to the heating substations. A simulation platform with 16 agents was used to conduct the project (Fig. 6 ). Each agent is composed of a computing process node (CPN) as a core component, a local controller, a monitoring panel, signal display lamps and manual regulation knobs. They communicate information with each other via local area networks (LANs) interconnecting with CPNs to share prospective behaviors. 5.2 Time-series data collection To generate valid GRU-based prediction models for the indoor temperature of public buildings and then implant them into the MPCs of consumer agents, time-series data on heating from a four-story classroom building with 9545 m2 area and a height of 17 m in Dalian, China were collected. In the building, convectors are used for supplying heat to rooms, and their heat load is approximately 561.3 kW based on engineering calculations. The data were collected from 26 December 2020, at 0:00 a.m., to 14 January 2021, at 10:00 a.m., with a 15-min sampling interval. The measured data consisted of the indoor temperature T i , weather parameters including the outdoor temperature T o , solar radiation I s and wind velocity V d , as well as heating parameters with water flow G w , and supplied and returned water temperature T w , s and T w , r , respectively. Indoor temperature was measured using 16 temperature sensors distributed evenly in the building. All measured data are provided in an attachment with the suffix.zip. Herein, the current indoor temperature works as the output, and weather parameters, heating parameters and the past indoor temperature serve as inputs in the GRU-based prediction model. Fig. 7 shows the measured data, excluding the indoor temperature. To obtain credible prediction models, we selected the top 1300 samples (70%) as the training datasets and reserved the remaining samples (30%) for testing to validate the GRU network. All selected variables were normalized between [−1, 1] before use, to prevent the dominant effect of particular variables [48]. 6 Results and discussion This section presents the validation results and discussion of the proposed methods, including the GRU-based prediction model, improved SPH set-point reset strategies and distributed overall optimization strategy for a simplified DH system as a typical large-scale HVAC system. 6.1 GRU-based prediction model Based on the above time-series data, the one-time step (15 min in advance) and multi-time step (30 min in advance) ahead forecasts for indoor temperature with the GRU network are presented in Fig. 8 and Fig. 9 respectively. The comparison results of the GRU network with the BP, Elman and LSTM networks are listed in Table 1 . As can be seen in Figs. 8 and 9 and Table 1, the multi-time step-ahead forecasting results were slightly worse than those of the one-time step because the predicted output is regarded as one of the inputs for the next time step in the former. The LSTM network outperformed the others in reflecting the relationship between indoor temperature and its influencing factors with relatively minimal RMSE and MAPE. Owing to the lack of memory function, the BP network was unable to handle time-series information with time delays well, with the least R 2 . The Elman neural network (ENN), as a full RNN, improved the forecasting capacity by adding a cyclic connection, compared with the feedforward network. As variants of RNN, the LSTM network and GRU network avoided vanishing and exploding gradients within BPTT; thus, their performance in dealing with temporal information was superior, with RMSE values of 63.70% and 66.93% of that of Elman respectively. However, additional parameters increased the computational burden, that is, the training time increased. Relatively speaking, the GRU network can be seen as a compromise option whose computational expense is less than that of the LSTM network, while performing not much worse. Therefore, the GRU network, as a credible tool, for establishing a model between indoor temperature and tunable variables, can be implanted into the MPCs of consumer agents to identify their real-time demands. 6.2 SPH set-point reset strategy To compare the performance of the different SPH set-point reset strategies, the real-time maximum valve position and corresponding SPH set-point under each strategy are shown in Fig. 10 . The fuzzy rule is illustrated in Fig. 11 . The Max-AE of the maximum valve position and its violation number, as well as the RF of SPH set-point, are listed in Table 3. Pre-set parameters are listed in Table 2 . The SPH set-point reset strategy based on the fuzzy rule outperformed the others in minimizing the RF of the SPH set-point, but with the worst Max-AE of the maximum valve position and its highest violation number (Table 3). Compared with the former, the linear rule improved the control performance with a smaller Max-AE reduction by 84.31% (Table 3). However, the RF of the SPH set-point was the highest, increasing by 32.04% compared to the former (Table 3). Self-adjusting universe fuzzy rule is a compromise choice to retain the advantages of the fixed fuzzy rule and not introduce the shortcomings of the linear rule. However, reestablishing a novel fuzzy rule for each time step may require more time. Impressively, the hybrid rule that inherits the merits of fixed fuzzy and linear rules is more competitive than the self-adjusting universe fuzzy rule. It possesses the least Max-AE, and its RF is also less than that of the former, which can act as the optimal SPH set-point reset strategy. 6.3 Data-oriented distributed optimization In the hardware-in-the-loop simulation, we gave the indoor temperature set-points required by occupants as 17.5 °C, 17.0 °C, 16.5 °C and 16.0 °C in turn, and the allowable deviation range was ± 0.1 °C . The physical characters of pumps in two heating substations are presented in Table 4 . For the sake of clarity, we also implemented another strategy, marked strategy 2, in which the traditional centralized architecture is employed, the GRU model-based predictive control is still adopted, the SPH set-point is determined by calculating the real-time hydraulic resistance and the PSO algorithm works on the overall optimization. All simulation results are presented in Fig. 12 . As can be seen in Fig. 12 and Table 5 , although MPCs successfully perceived future weather parameters, the PSO algorithm cannot always obtain excellent outcomes for the high-dimensional space in the overall optimization, and RMSEs of indoor temperature under strategy 2 were approximately 10 times than those under strategy 1. The corresponding violation numbers beyond indoor set temperatures increased by 91.5%, and even the former Max-AE of indoor temperature was 50 times that of the latter in some cases (Fig. 12 (b) and Table 5). Furthermore, because of information-share delays in resetting the SPH set-point by calculating the real-time hydraulic resistance, the SPH frequently fluctuated, which resulted in continual adjustments of pumps in heating substations (in Fig. 12 (e)–(h), the rotation speed ratio is equal to zero, which means that the corresponding pump is off, and the rotation speed ratios are consistent for the same pumps.). In this strategy, the valve positions were not considered into the overall optimization such that the maximum valve position was out of the optimal valve position domain most of the time (Fig. 12 (j)) and more valve positions emerged in the low valve position range ((Fig. 12 (k))); thus, approximately 4% more energy was consumed (Table 5). Moreover, more time cost must be paid under strategy 2. These defects are further exposed with the scale of the HVAC system. In the agent-based distributed overall optimization framework, the information between agents is shared promptly, and the bi-level optimization algorithm serves to decrease the computational complexity to seek optimal solutions. The SPH set-point strategy based on hybrid rules can ensure thermal comfort for occupants with relatively less energy consumption. 7 Conclusion This study focused on the overall optimization of increasingly complex HVAC systems with DSC and DDR to develop a data-oriented distributed optimization strategy. For the unilateral and non-interfering distributed optimization schemes for multi-zone buildings and equipment groups at present, we proposed an agent-based distributed overall optimization framework, and designed a bi-level optimization algorithm to implement it, and presented a series of data-oriented optimization models to cater to increasingly widespread monitoring networks. A hardware-in-the-loop simulation was performed, and the real time-series data were collected to validate our proposed distributed optimization strategy. The following conclusions were drawn: a) For a large-scale HVAC system with DSC and DDR, the agent-based distributed overall optimization framework defines the roles of participants in distributed optimization and clarifies their duties, mechanisms, and relationships with each other, thus bridging the supply-side and demand-side decisions, which offers a universal optimization mode for increasingly complex HVAC systems. b) To achieve the agent-based distributed overall optimization framework, a data-oriented distributed optimization strategy is developed, in which state-of-the-art data-driven models are invoked to adapt to increasingly widespread monitoring networks, and a bi-level optimization algorithm is designed to serve to decrease the computational complexity to seek optimal solutions. As for the precise identification of demands, the GRU network, as a compromise option, can effectively express the relationship between indoor temperature and its influencing factors and its fewer additional parameters reduce the computational burden while performing not much worse than the LSTM network. The bi-level optimization algorithm, where the PSO algorithm works as the lower-level scheme and the Nash optimization algorithm acts as the upper-level scheme, can decompose the complex optimization problem into multiple parallel handy subproblems with coupling. Compared with the PSO algorithm under the centralized architecture, it can obtain better control performance by paying a lower time cost, and the merits will be further expanded with the scale of the HVAC system. c) The SPH set-point reset strategy avoids the complex calculations and optimization operations in the model calibration method. Besides, compared with the hydraulic resistance calculation method based on real-time data, valve positions are concerned with optimization, which can reduce energy consumption. Furthermore, for promoting the stability and security of HVAC systems, a self-adjusting universe fuzzy rule and hybrid rule for SPH set-point reset are developed. Relatively speaking, the hybrid rule inheriting the merits of the fuzzy and linear rules performs more competitively, with the least Max-AE of the maximum valve position and the lower RF of the SPH set-point, which can be selected as the optimal SPH set-point reset strategy. In the future, more strategies for optimizing the overall HVAC system with DSC and DDR will be further investigated. In addition, the proposed optimization strategy will be validated in practical engineering. coredata.dc:description: Operational optimization of heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems is crucial to achieving economic and environmental benefits. However, owing to the dynamic supply capability (DSC) and distributed demand response (DDR), large-scale HVAC systems that integrate multiple distributed sources with demanders are increasingly being developed to resemble distributed energy systems (DESs); thus, the traditional centralized strategies are now facing unprecedented challenges. With the application of wireless communication and sensor network technology, distributed schemes that allow the modular integration of an arbitrary number of suppliers and demanders have attached widespread interest of researchers. However, existing distributed optimization schemes that focus on either multi-zone temperature or equipment group efficiency are unilateral and non-interfering. In this work, we developed a data-oriented distributed overall optimization strategy for large-scale HVAC systems with DSC and DDR. We first suggested an agent-based distributed overall optimization framework that defines the roles of participants in distributed optimization and clarifies their duties, mechanisms, and relationships with each other, thus bridging the supply-side and demand-side decisions. Then, we exploited state-of-the-art data-driven models and designed a bi-level optimization algorithm, where the heuristic algorithm works as the lower-level scheme and the Nash-optimization algorithm acts as the upper-level scheme, to implement the distributed overall optimization. Last, a hardware-in-the-loop simulation was performed, and time-series data were collected to validate our proposed optimization strategy. Compared with centralized strategies, it can obtain better operational performance by paying a lower computational cost. This work provides a reference for optimizing increasingly complex HVAC systems.
coredata.dc:title: Data-oriented distributed overall optimization for large-scale HVAC systems with dynamic supply capability and distributed demand response
